questions.text: A 6-year-old child at a private vaccination centre received scheduled immunizations against diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis throughout the first 2 years of his life. Upon boosting, he demonstrated increased antibody affinity to binding diphtheria antigens. The mechanism that affects immunoglobulin antigen binding affinity which occurs after formation of a mature B cell is:

A 4-year-old female child has eczema, with a large scaly red rash covering her elbows and knees. Scratches were evident on her torso, with infected lesions prominently on the inside of her elbows. She was diagnosed with atopic dermatitis. Stimulation of PBMCs ( Peripheral blood mononuclear cells )with concanavalin A produced IL-4, IL-6, and IL-10. Which statement best describes her T-lymphocyte response?

options.label: C
options.text: They give help to B cells to produce immunoglobulins.

options.label: D
options.text: They primarily secrete IL-2 and IFN-g

questions.correct_answer: C. They give help to B cells to produce immunoglobulins.
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • B. They suppress cytotoxic T-cell function – Incorrect While IL-10 has immunosuppressive properties and can dampen excessive immune responses, Th2 cells do not directly function to suppress cytotoxic T cells (CD8+ T cells). Instead, regulatory T cells (Tregs) are responsible for suppressing cytotoxic T-cell function by secreting IL-10 and TGF-β. The primary role of Th2 cells in this scenario is enhancing B cell activity, not suppressing cytotoxic T cells.
  • • D. They primarily secrete IL-2 and IFN-γ – Incorrect IL-2 and IFN-γ are characteristic cytokines of T-helper 1 (Th1) cells, which are involved in cell-mediated immunity against intracellular pathogens. Th1 cells activate macrophages and cytotoxic T cells to combat viral and bacterial infections, but they are not the dominant players in atopic dermatitis. Since the patient’s immune response is Th2-skewed, with IL-4, IL-6, and IL-10 production, this answer is incorrect.

questions.text: A 14-year-old female presents with shortness of breath, persistent cough, and chest pain. A chest radiograh shows “cotton ball” densities in both lungs, which are determined to be Aspergillus fumigatus. Her WBC count is normal. Molecular analysis reveals that she is unable to metabolize nitro blue tetrazolium due to a defect in NADPH oxidase. The most likely diagnosis for this child is which of the following?

A patient in rural area developed symptoms of runny nose, fever, and cough. He visited a quack in the village, who incorrectly diagnosed the viral infection as being of bacterial in origin. He prescribed a bolus dose of ampicillin given intravenously. Within 24 hours, the patient developed fever, skin rashes, petechial hemorrhaging of the lower extremities, edema, glandular enlargement, and severe pain in the joints. Which type of hypersensitive reaction is occurring?
Innate immune receptors that recognize highly conserved molecules within microbial species include all of the following except:

A 25-year-old woman has an erythematous rash on the malar eminences of her face that gets worse when she is exposed to sunlight. She has generalized joint pain and feels tiredmuch of the time. Physical examination is normal except for the rash. Laboratory tests reveal a WBC count of 5500/mm3 (normal). Urinalysis shows elevated levels of protein in the urine but no RBCs, WBCs, or bacteria. Which one of the following is the most likely laboratory finding in this disease?

options.label: A
options.text: Decreased number of helper (CD4+) T cells

options.label: C
options.text: High levels of antibodies to double-stranded DNA

options.label: D
options.text: Increased number of cytotoxic T cells

questions.correct_answer: C. High levels of antibodies to double-stranded DNA

questions.text: A 28-year-old female gives birth to a first child who is identified as being Rh positive. Although the mother is Rh negative, she was not treated after birth with anti-Rh antibodies. During the next pregnancy, the fetus is found to have erythroblastosis fetalis. Which isotype of maternal immunoglobulin is responsible for the hemolytic disease of the newborn?

A 45 year-old female presents to the clinic with complaints of persistent cough, night sweats, loss of weight, and recent blood-streaked sputum. Her chest radiograph reveals lung infiltrates, with cavitation in the upper right lobe. Acid-fast organisms grow from cultured sputum and bronchoalveolar lavage fluid, which are identified as Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Components directly involved in the mycobacterial granulomatous response include all of the following except:

A 38-year-old woman while on a vacation in Mumbai is brought to your clinic by travel agent, the patient complains of vomiting, nausea, diarrhea, and abdominal pain. The previous evening she had visited a restaurant and had consumed food that was contaminated with Staphylococcus aureus. Her body temperature was significantly elevated. Which combination of macrophage-derived molecules is directly involved in systemic temperature elevation during Staphylococcus aureus infection?

A 20 -year-old female athlete presents to the hospital with complaint of fever lasting several days. She had no localized symptoms other than development of a large rash as shown in the image below. Further history reveals she is a professional horse rider and was taking horse riding lessons in USA. The organism causing her infection is most likely which of the following?

A 60-year-old female presents to the casualty with presumed cellulitis on her left lower leg after getting a splinter in her foot, she is a known case of diabetes non compliant to medications. Her heel has a bluish hematoma with significant medial erythema. Laboratory result on peripheral blood demonstrated an elevated WBC count of 23,400/mm3 (normal, 4000 to 12,000/mL) with a left shift. Radiography showed extensive gas in the soft tissues (as shown in image). A Gram stain of the wound aspirate revealed only rare presence of neutrophils, and boxcar-shaped, gram positive rods. The organism most likely is:
Among the given options which is the correct sequence of events in the development of an effective immune response during a viral infection:

options.label: A
options.text: INF-γ production, NK cell–mediated killing, T-cell immune response

options.label: B
options.text: T-cell immune response, INF-γ production, ADCC

options.label: C
options.text: Antibody synthesis, INF-γ production, NK cell ADCC

options.label: D
options.text: INF-γ production, antibody synthesis, INF-γ production

options.label: E
options.text: NK cell INF-γ production, INF-γ production, T-cell immune response

questions.correct_answer: A. INF-γ production, NK cell–mediated killing, T-cell immune response
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • The T-cell immune response occurs later, while INF-γ production is an early event in viral infections. Antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC) relies on antibodies, which are produced later in the immune response. This sequence does not accurately reflect the natural order of events. C. Antibody synthesis, INF-γ production, NK cell ADCC
  • • Antibody synthesis is a late-stage response, requiring activation of B cells and class switching, making it unlikely to be the first event. INF-γ production occurs early, before antibodies are synthesized. NK cell activity occurs before antibody-mediated ADCC, as it is part of the innate response. D. INF-γ production, antibody synthesis, INF-γ production
  • • INF-γ production is an early event, but antibody synthesis is a later adaptive immune response that occurs only after T-cell activation and B-cell maturation. The repetition of INF-γ production does not fit into the proper immune response sequence. E. NK cell INF-γ production, INF-γ production, T-cell immune response
  • • NK cell activity and INF-γ production happen early, but this sequence lacks the intermediate step of NK cell-mediated killing, which is crucial before the T-cell immune response becomes effective. The redundancy of INF-γ production is also incorrect in this order.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female has been brought to the emergency department with complaints of mental confusion. Her parents report she had developed malaise, headache, and fever over a 2-month period, which progressed to general body pain. She does not recall any acute trauma. The patient has a history of bite by a dog with noticeable behavioral changes. On investigation the patient is found to have a high CD8+ cell count. Which agent is most likely responsible for the infection?

A 27-year-old female presents to the dermatologist with complaint of itchy lesions on her upper back. The lesions are scaly, white and patchy ( as shown in image). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis of the agent responsible?

15. A 59-year-old female, with uncontrolled diabetes mellitus (DM), suffered COVID-19 in January 2021 with a positive polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and was managed with broad spectrum antibiotics for bacterial pneumonia on top of viral pneumonitis and corticosteroids in a dose exceeding 90/mg per day. The patient presented to the hospital 21/days post COVID-19 with 2/weeks duration of unilateral right facial swelling and deviation of angle of the mouth to the left, complete ophthalmoplegia, no perception of light, and ptosis along the right eye. An elevated skin lesion with dark discoloration along the forehead and right cheek as well as decreased sensation along maxillary division of trigeminal nerve was noted. Sampling of fluid in his ethmoid sinuses recovered a calcofluor white–staining agent with broad, aseptate hyphae. Which class of agent was likely identified?

A 28 year old homosexual male presents to his physician with bilateral inguinal buboes (lymph nodes), one of which seems ready to rupture. He recalls having two small, painless genital lesions that healed rapidly. The etiologic agent is isolated using McCoy cells. Which of the following statements is correct regarding disease in question ?

options.label: A
options.text: It is most common in temperate regions

options.label: B
options.text: The causative agent is C. trachomatis

options.label: D
options.text: Penicillin is effective in early treatment

questions.correct_answer: B. The causative agent is C. trachomatis

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of 3 days of foul-smelling, watery diarrhea without any fever. The patient reports significant abdominal cramping. The stool does not contain blood but has evidence of steatorrhea (fatty deposits). The organism most likely responsible for the symptoms is:

A 25-year-old college going male presents to the OPD with complaints of a fever, headache, muscle aches, and swollen glands. The physician observes disseminated lymphadenopathy, pharyngitis, and a rash on the man’s upper chest. On further probing the patient states that he had been to a rave party 2 weeks ago where he experimented with injecting drugs to get high. Needles were shared among the party-goers. A rapid latex test for human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) antibodies performed in the physician’s office is negative. The doctor has a strong suspicion that this man has acute retroviral syndrome. Which of the following tests is most likely to support a diagnosis of HIV infection at this time?

options.label: B
options.text: HIV antibody test by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (EIA)

options.label: D
options.text: Reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (PCR) for HIV RNA

questions.correct_answer: D. Reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (PCR) for HIV RNA

questions.text: A 67-year-old man has been brought to the medicine OPD with complaints of poor memory and difficulty with vision that was progressing rapidly and myoclonic jerks. Cerebrospinal fluid examination at a reference laboratory revealed the presence of 14-3-3 protein. Over the next 6 months his cognitive deterioration became severe and he died 2 months later. At autopsy, spongiform encephalopathy was noted. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnosis for this man?

An outbreak of hepatitis occurred in a slum area of Mumbai with poor sanitation. Most of the patients reported fever, nausea with vomiting, and weight loss occurring over several days followed by jaundice and pruritus. Testing quickly ruled out HAV. A number of women in the area are pregnant. For which of the following are these women at risk?

A 14 year old boy in the village had gone for a swimming where he suffered a foot laceration while swimming in a polluted water area in a river. He did not seek medical treatment, and the wound developed a foul-smelling exudate. One of the bacteria isolated from the abscess exudate was missing superoxide dismutase, catalase, and a peroxidase. Which of the following statements best describes this microorganism?

options.label: C
options.text: It is a microaerophiled. It is an anaerobe

questions.text: A 45 year old male presents to casualty with complaints of abdominal pain, cramping, bloody diarrhea, and nausea, he tells that he had consumed undercooked meat a day ago in a party. An isolate from the stool is biochemically identified as Salmonella enterica; however, the isolate cannot be serotyped. Which of the following has this organism lost?

After a street food festival in Delhi an outbreak of diarrhea has occur which is thought to be related to a group of vendors who were selling chat and pani puri at the fair. Stool cultures are positive for Shigella in almost all individuals who ate the pani puri. Growth of the isolated colonies in nutrient liquid medium without the transfer to fresh medium will eventually induce the death phase of the organism. Which of the following is a limiting factor in microbial growth under laboratory conditions?

options.label: C
options.text: Accumulation of toxic products in the growth medium

questions.correct_answer: C. Accumulation of toxic products in the growth medium

questions.text: A 48-year-old alcoholic man presents to the clinic with fever, chills, cough, a chest X ray is obtained suggestive of pneumonia. The Gram-stained smear of sputum shows many PMNs and gram-positive cocci in pairs and chains. Which of the following is the correct order of the procedural steps when performing the Gram stain?

options.label: A
options.text: Fixation, crystal violet, alcohol/acetone decolorization, safranin

options.label: B
options.text: Fixation, crystal violet, iodine treatment, alcohol/acetone decolorization, safranin

options.label: C
options.text: Fixation, crystal violet, iodine treatment, safranin

questions.correct_answer: B. Fixation, crystal violet, iodine treatment, alcohol/acetone decolorization, safranin

questions.text: 57 prison mates are hospitalized with bloody diarrhea. Several of them develop fever, abdominal pain, and severe hematological abnormalities. An investigation establishes that all of these individuals developed symptoms following consumption of bad food in prison. Which of the following tests is the best to detect the most likely etiologic agent of this outbreak?

options.label: B
options.text: Immunoassay for Shiga toxin-producing Escherichia coli

options.label: D
options.text: Serologic testing for Salmonella enterica antibodies

questions.correct_answer: B. Immunoassay for Shiga toxin-producing Escherichia coli

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl has been referred from a rural PHC to the district hospital with a sore throat, fever, malaise, and difficulty breathing. The girl has never been vaccinated. A gray membrane covering the pharynx is observed on physical examination. Corynebacterium diphtheriae is confirmed as the etiologic agent of this infection. Which of the following is required to prove that C. diphtheriae is the etiologic agent of this child’s infection?

options.label: B
options.text: Isolation of C. diphtheriae from throat culture

options.label: C
options.text: Metachromatic granules seen on methylene blue stain

options.label: D
options.text: Toxigenicity demonstrated by the Elek test

questions.correct_answer: D. Toxigenicity demonstrated by the Elek test

questions.text: A 45 year old female HIV-positive patient, after treatment with Zidovudine, lamivudine plus ritonavir, has a CD4 T-cell count of 325/µL and a viral load of less than 50 copies of HIV RNA/mL. Previously her CD4+ T-cell count was 280/µL and viral load was 100,000 copies/mL. Which of the following best describes this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: This patient is no longer in danger of opportunistic infection

options.label: C
options.text: The antiretroviral therapy has been effective

questions.correct_answer: C. The antiretroviral therapy has been effective

questions.text: A 29-year-old intravenous (IV) drug abuser who is a known case of chronic hepatitis B virus (HBV) status suddenly presents with an acute hepatitis episode. He develops massive hepatic necrosis and even after best medical efforts he dies. Which of the following is most likely responsible for the change in his condition?

options.label: A
options.text: A hepatitis B mutant has developed

options.label: B
options.text: He has contracted hepatitis D virus (HDV)

options.label: D
options.text: His food contained hepatitis A virus (HAV)

questions.correct_answer: B. He has contracted hepatitis D virus (HDV)

questions.text: A 35 year old sexually active woman visits the clinic for a routine gynecologic exam that include a Pap smear. The report indicated cervical intraepithelial neoplasia. In situ hybridization showed the presence of human papillomavirus (HPV) type 16 genomes within the neoplastic cells. Which of the following processes is required for HPV to lead to the development of cancer?

options.label: B
options.text: Loss of HPV E6 and E7 genes

questions.correct_answer: A. Integration of the viral genome

questions.text: A 1 year old child who was born 4 weeks premature was brought to the Emergency Department with high fever, rhinorrhea, cough, and difficulty breathing. On examination, the baby had dyspnea and tachypnea; rales and wheezing were heard over both lungs. The baby was admitted to Pediatric Intensive Care where she suffered respiratory failure and was placed on mechanical ventilation. Two different types of tests for respiratory syncytial virus (RSV or Pneumovirus) were negative, as were tests for parainfluenza virus, influenza A and B viruses, and adenovirus. Which of the following viruses is the most likely etiologic agent?

A 30 year old patient with a burning epigastric pain is admitted to the hospital, and a gastric biopsy is performed. The tissue is cultured on chocolate agar incubated in a microaerophilic environment at 98.6°F (37°C) for 5 to 7 days. On fifth day of incubation, colonies appear on the plate and curved, gram-negative, oxidase-positive rods are observed. Which of the following is the most likely identity of this organism?

A 30-year-old working woman presents to the gynecology department with vaginitis. She had no sexual intercourse in past 6 months. She complains of a slightly increased, malodorous dis charge that is gray-white in color, thin, and homogenous. Image of microscopic examination is given below. Which of the following organisms is the most likely cause of her infection?

A 23-year-old college student presents to the hospital with worsening abdominal pain on investigations its found to be a case of a ruptured appendix. A peritoneal infection develops, despite prompt removal of the organ and extensive flushing of the peritoneal cavity. An isolate from a pus culture reveals a gram-negative rod identified as Bacteroides fragilis. Anaerobic infection with B. fragilis is best characterized by which of the following?

options.label: A
options.text: A black exudate in the wound

options.label: D
options.text: An exquisite sus ceptibility to penicillin

questions.text: A 38-year-old diabetic male notices maceration of the web space of his toes on the right foot. Two days later he has a temperature of up to 100°F, exquisite tenderness, erythema, and swelling of the right leg. Culture exudate from the foot yields S. aureus. Which of the following often complicates treatment of S. aureus infection with penicillin?

options.label: A
options.text: Allergic reaction caused by staphylococcal protein

options.label: B
options.text: Inability of penicillin to penetrate the membrane of S. aureus

options.label: C
options.text: Production of penicillinase by S. aureus

options.label: D
options.text: Production of penicillin acetylase by S. aureus

questions.correct_answer: C. Production of penicillinase by S. aureus

questions.text: A 45 year old patient receiving corticosteroid treatment for lupus developed headache and fever and when she began to display some memory loss she was brought to her physician by her spouse. Considered in the differential diagnosis was cryptococcal meningitis. Which of the following, if found upon examination of cerebrospinal fluid would support that diagnosis?

Among a cricket team several players comes to the team physician with complaint of a sudden onset of athlete’s foot (tinea pedis). Which of the following observations in a skin scraping will support the diagnosis?

A family visited different Indian states during a one week vacation. Approximately eight days after their trip, two family members began experiencing diarrhea. They went to their family physician and reported that while they were traveling they swam in hotel pools and at a waterpark. The physician requested stool samples for an ova and parasite (O & P) examination, along with other testing. The samples collected for the O & P were preserved in 10% formalin and then sent for examination. Figure below shows rounded objects seen on a modified acid-fast stained slide made from a formalin-ethyl acetate (FEA) concentrate of one of the specimens. The same objects were seen in specimens from the other family member who was ill. The objects measured 4.5-5.5 micrometers in diameter. What is your diagnosis?

As part of a screening program conducted by ministry of health, a young child had a fecal ova and parasite examination which included a formalin-ethyl acetate (FEA) fecal concentration. Objects shown in Figures were detected in low numbers on a wet mount preparation and measured about 75 micrometers on average. What is your diagnosis?

A group of athletes traveled to Brazil for world championship, after the tournament ended they went for a rafting and camping trip for two weeks. Malaria prophylaxis was highly recommended however one athlete declined as he feared it might affect his performance. The one athlete who declined prophylaxis developed headache, fever, and chills two days after returning from the trip. He sought medical attention at the hospital and a blood smear was prepared, stained with Wrights stain and examined for parasites. Figures show what was detected. What is your diagnosis ?

A 8-month-old male infant is brought to the hospital emergency department at night with severe middle ear and upper respiratory tract infections, the resident on duty started him on broad spectrum antibiotics to which he responded promptly. Two months later he is again admitted, this time with Streptococcus pneumoniae pneumonia. After several more episodes of bacterial infections, genetic testing is done and the presence of a defective B-cell tyrosine kinase gene (btk gene or X-LA gene) is revealed. In addition, physical examination detects very small tonsils. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: D
options.text: Late (C5, C6, C7, C8, C9) complement deficiency

questions.text: A young girl has been brought to the pediatrics department, her past medical records show that she had repeated infections with Candida albicans and respiratory viruses since she was 3 months old. The consultant wants to do a thorough clinical evaluation of her immune status, as a part of which her responses to routine immunization procedures should be tested. In this evaluation, the use of which of the following vaccines is contraindicated?
Which of the following statements best applies to the following diagram?

options.label: A
options.text: Depicts the cell-membrane MHC product associated with narcolepsy

options.label: B
options.text: Essential for the transplacental passage of antibody

options.label: C
options.text: Found on T and B lymphocytes and all nucleated cellsd. Present on macrophages but not neutrophils

options.label: D
options.text: Present on macrophages but not neutrophils

questions.correct_answer: C. Found on T and B lymphocytes and all nucleated cellsd. Present on macrophages but not neutrophils

questions.text: The complement system, also known as complement cascade, is a part of the immune system that enhances the ability of antibodies and phagocytic cells. Which of the following components of the complement system most important in chemotaxis ?

An 8-month-old male infant with a history of chronic diarrhea, otitis media, and several episodes of pneumonia presents to your clinic with gingivostomatitis (due to herpes simplex virus) and oral candidiasis (thrush). You immediately order an x-ray and a blood workup. X-ray and laboratory blood analysis reveal the absence of a thymic shadow and absence of B lymphocytes, respectively. History taken from the infant’s mother reveals a rash evident at birth. Which of the following diseases is most likely present in this infant?

A 25-year-old female patient presents to the emergency room she is 20 weeks pregnant and complains of 4-day history of fever, chills, and myalgia. Two days prior to this, she had noted painful genital lesions that had begun as vesicles. Pelvic examination revealed extensive vesicular and ulcerative lesions on the left labia minora and majora with marked edema, and inguinal lymphadenopathy. Which of the microorganisms causing genital ulcers can be demonstrated by dark field micros copy?

A 40-year-old male from a village of eastern uttar pradesh presents to the emergency room of medical college with high fever and malaise, which he reports that it began 4 days ago and got progressively worse each day. He appears underweight and very ill. Physical examination reveals needle marks in both antecubital fossae. Upon listening for heart sounds, a distinctive systolic heart murmur is heard. The physician order blood cultures and make a presumptive diagnosis of acute bacterial endocarditis. Following is the growth curve of the organism growing in a nutrient medium at 35°C with both O2 and added CO2 present. In which of the following growth phases would the organism most likely be resistant to β-lactam antibiotics?

A 35-year-old female traveller presents to the clinic with complaints of headache, fever, abdominal cramps, and constipation, she gives a history of travel to crowded cities in south India. The physician orders a blood culture which comes positive for Salmonella enterica Serovar Typhimurium. Her condition improves with a treatment course of a ciprofloxacin. Which of the following is the function of porins that would prevent the effective use of this antimicrobial?

options.label: B
options.text: Transfer of molecules through the outer membrane

options.label: C
options.text: Serologic stabilization of the O antigen

questions.correct_answer: B. Transfer of molecules through the outer membrane

questions.text: Following a food poisoning outbreak the food inspection team took certain samples from the restaurant from which strains of E. coli were isolated some were tetracycline resistant while the others were susceptible. However, when tetracycline-resistant and -susceptible strains were grown together, all of them became tetracycline resistant. This efficient transfer of resistance depends on which of the following?

options.label: A
options.text: Cell lysis and the release of DNA from donor bacteria

questions.text: A research microbiologist is conducting experiments on E. coli, He observes that E. coli has a doubling time of 30 minutes in human urine at room temperature. A patient had 1000 bacteria per mL of urine when a urine specimen was collected. How many bacteria would be present if the specimen sat at room temperature for 4 hours before being plated for culture in the laboratory?

An 8-year-old boy presents to the pediatric OPD with a history of fever and nonspecific symptoms presents with a bright red cheeks (as shown in the image)and a macular lacy rash over his body. Which of the following viruses is the most likely cause of this disease?

A 30 year old female presents to the hospital in labour, her past history is evident for painful vesicular lesions on her genitalia for several days for which she had not sought medical help until she was in heavy labor. At admission to labor and delivery, internal lesions were seen on her cervix and vaginal walls, but the birth was eminent. The newborn infant developed vesicular skin lesions along with generalized symptoms suggestive of CNS and liver involvement. Which of the following is the most rapid test for definitive identification of the most likely etiologic agent?

options.label: A
options.text: Detection of specific HSV IgG antibodies

options.label: B
options.text: Direct immunofluorescence for HSV on cells from lesions

questions.correct_answer: B. Direct immunofluorescence for HSV on cells from lesions

questions.text: A street person well known to the local public health clinic appears to have acute symptoms of hepatitis and tests positive for HDV antigen. Knowing that HDV requires HBV, which of the following sets of test results shows this patient had chronic HBV infection and was superinfected with HDV?

options.label: A
options.text: HBsAg +, HBeAg +, Anti-HBcAg IgM +, Anti-HBcAg IgG -, Anti-HBsAg -

options.label: B
options.text: HBsAg +, HBeAg +, Anti-HBcAg IgM -, Anti-HBcAg IgG +, Anti-HBsAg -

options.label: C
options.text: HBsAg -, HBeAg -, Anti-HBcAg IgM -, Anti-HBcAg IgG +, Anti-HBsAg +

options.label: D
options.text: HBsAg -, HBeAg -, Anti-HBcAg IgM -, Anti-HBcAg IgG -, Anti-HBsAg +

questions.correct_answer: B. HBsAg +, HBeAg +, Anti-HBcAg IgM -, Anti-HBcAg IgG +, Anti-HBsAg -
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • HBsAg (+), HBeAg (+), Anti-HBc IgM (+), Anti-HBc IgG (-), Anti-HBs (-) The presence of IgM anti-HBc suggests acute HBV infection rather than chronic HBV. HDV superinfection occurs in those with chronic HBV, not acute infection. Since this patient has HDV superinfection, they must already have a chronic HBV infection, making this option incorrect. Option C:
  • • HBsAg (-), HBeAg (-), Anti-HBc IgM (-), Anti-HBc IgG (+), Anti-HBs (+) Anti-HBc IgG (+) and Anti-HBs (+) indicate past HBV infection with recovery. Since HBsAg is negative, there is no active HBV infection, which means HDV cannot be present (HDV requires HBV). This contradicts the case scenario, making this option incorrect. Option D:
  • • HBsAg (-), HBeAg (-), Anti-HBc IgM (-), Anti-HBc IgG (-), Anti-HBs (+) Anti-HBs (+) but no Anti-HBc IgG suggests the patient was vaccinated against HBV but was never infected. Since HBsAg is negative, there is no current HBV infection, and therefore HDV infection is not possible. This directly contradicts the presence of HDV antigen, making the option incorrect.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman working at a NGO was bitten on the fingers by a cat. She self cleaned the wounds, and after a week, the sites healed without bacterial infection. Sixty days later, she noticed pain, itching, and numbness at the sites of the bite wounds. She got scared and immediately made an appointment to see the physician next day. To physician she complained that her arm is paralyzed, and she is febrile, has a headache, and is very anxious. Doctor advice a nuchal skin biopsy. The H&E stain showed viral inclusion bodies and direct fluorescent antibody test with virus-specific antiserum was positive. With which virus was this woman infected?

A labourer working in the biomedical waste management facility of a hospital is found to be positive for hepatitis B surface antigen. Subsequent tests reveal the presence of HBeAg as well. Which of the following best describes the worker?

options.label: A
options.text: Has a biologic false-positive test for hepatitis

questions.text: A 47-year-old male patient who is a known case of AIDS presented to the hospital for evaluation of skin lesions. He had numerous plaque-like lesions over his arms, chest, and neck . Oral examination revealed the lesion shown in the image on his palate. What is the most likely etiologic agent of these lesions?

An 70-year-old beggar who has been living on urban streets for long time and has not taken bath since at least a month is brought to the emergency room. Patient complains he has constant headaches, and a fever that comes and goes about every 5 days. He also complains of great pains in his legs. The ward boy say that when they cut off his clothes, they found lice. You suspect that he has trench fever caused by which organism?

A 32 year old male presents to the casualty with complaints of fever, and a painful, inflamed wound on his hand( as shown in image ). A scraping from the wound is found to contain numerous gram-negative bacteria. Upon questioning, the patient states that he was bitten by a cat while trying to rescue it from a drain earlier in the day. Based on history and examination of patient, which of the following organisms is the most likely cause of infection?

A 7-year-old girl residing in mumbai is brought to the dermatology clinic with scaly patches and areas of alopecia on the scalp with hair shafts broken off close to the scalp. The hair did not fluoresce under Wood’s light. If this child has tinea capitis, the most likely etiology is:

You are the infection control officer of the hospital, samples are taken from the bone marrow transplant unit, from the standpoint of frequency and lethality, which of the following fungi should be your biggest concern?

A 35 year old AIDS patient with CD4 count < 200/μL presents to the hospital with a 2-week history of watery, nonbloody diarrhea. Acid-fast staining demonstrates oocysts in fresh stool seen in the figure below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Acid-fast bacilli refer to Mycobacteria, which do not present as oocysts in stool. MAC (Mycobacterium avium complex) can cause diarrhea in AIDS patients, but it is diagnosed by blood cultures or intestinal biopsy, not stool examination. Mycobacteria are rod-shaped bacteria, not oocysts, making this an incorrect answer. Option B: Enterocytozoon (Microsporidia: Enterocytozoon bieneusi, Encephalitozoon spp.)
  • • Microsporidia are obligate intracellular fungi, also seen in AIDS patients with chronic diarrhea, but they are detected using modified trichrome stain, not acid-fast stain. Their spores are smaller than Cryptosporidium oocysts and do not match the described acid-fast positive oocysts in stool. Though microsporidiosis is a differential, Cryptosporidium is the most likely cause given the staining method used. Option D: Entamoeba histolytica
  • • E. histolytica causes amoebic dysentery, characterized by bloody diarrhea with flask-shaped ulcers in the colon, which is not seen here. Trophozoites or cysts of E. histolytica are identified in stool via wet mount or trichrome staining, not acid-fast stain. It does not form acid-fast oocysts, making it an incorrect choice.

questions.text: Concerned mother of a 5 year old boy brings her child to the pediatrician complaining she has noticed that the child’s frequent stools are malodorous, mushy, and greasy. The child has no fever, but does frequently complain of abdominal pain. The increase of fat in the stool directs the pediatrician’s concern toward a diagnosis of malabsorption syndrome associated with which of the following?

A 42 year old woman presents to the clinic with complaint of abdominal pain, the analysis of a patient’s stool reveals small structures resembling rice grains; microscopic examination shows these to be proglottids. Egg of the parasite is given below. Which of the following is the most likely organism in this patient’s stool?

A 39 year old businessman presents to the clinic complaining of jaundice and weakness. Physical examination points towards anemia. He gives a history of travel to Tiwan for a business trip. Which of the following is the most likely etiologic agent shown in the figure below?

A 32-year-old IV drug abuser presented with fever, cough, facial papules, and pustules. On further evaluation the patient was found to be HIV-positive. Microscopic examination of a stained smear of material obtained from a pustule showed structures that could be described as those stained red or dark in the periodic acid Schiff stained tissue specimen below. These pustular lesions are most likely attributable to infection with which of the following organisms.

A 22 -year-old college student presents to the in campus clinic complaining of a diffuse, painful rash extending from his mid thigh to his navel region. He gives a history that the rash started few weeks ago over which he applied an steroid ointment purchased from local pharmacy. A KOH scraping of the lesion reveals hyaline hyphae and a portion of the scraping is submitted for culture. Image of the microscopic observation of the culture is shown below. The most likely etiology is ?

A 32-year-old woman visits the gynecologist with complaint of vaginal and vulvar itching, a slightly watery discharge and pain with intercourse. On examination the vaginal pH was estimated as 4.4. Microscopic examination was performed on some Gram-stained dis charge material. The observation was similar to below. The most likely diagnosis is ?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Candida species, primarily Candida albicans, is a part of the normal vaginal flora but can overgrow when the vaginal environment is altered, such as in:
  • • Antibiotic use (reduces normal lactobacilli) Pregnancy or hormonal changes Diabetes mellitus Immunosuppression (e.g., HIV, corticosteroid use) Key Features of Vulvovaginal Candidiasis (VVC): Symptoms: Intense vulvar and vaginal itching Thick, white, cottage cheese-like discharge (though sometimes watery) Dyspareunia (painful intercourse) Erythema, swelling, and excoriation of the vulva Vaginal pH: Normal (≤ 4.5) Microscopy (Gram stain/KOH prep): Budding yeast, pseudohyphae, or true hyphae Treatment: Topical azoles (clotrimazole, miconazole) for mild cases Oral fluconazole for more severe or recurrent infections Explanation of Incorrect Options: (A) Bacterial Vaginosis (BV) – Incorrect
  • • BV is caused by Gardnerella vaginalis and other anaerobes, resulting in a fishy-smelling, thin grayish-white vaginal discharge. Vaginal pH is > 4.5, which is higher than normal due to loss of lactobacilli. Microscopy would show clue cells (epithelial cells covered with bacteria), not budding yeast or pseudohyphae. (C) Chlamydial Vaginitis – Incorrect
  • • Chlamydia trachomatis can cause cervicitis, vaginal discharge, and dysuria, but it typically does not cause significant itching or a thick discharge. Microscopy does not show yeast or hyphae; instead, nucleic acid amplification tests (NAATs) are required for diagnosis. Vaginal pH is usually unchanged or slightly elevated. (D) Trichomoniasis – Incorrect
  • • Trichomonas vaginalis, a motile protozoan, causes yellow-green, frothy, foul-smelling discharge, not the thick white discharge seen in candidiasis. Strawberry cervix (petechiae on cervix) may be present. Vaginal pH is elevated (> 4.5), whereas in this case, it is 4.4 (normal). Microscopy (wet mount) shows motile, flagellated protozoa, not yeast.

questions.text: A 40 year old farmer presents to the hospital with complaints of nasal obstruction, purulent rhinorrhea, odynophagia and a lesion inside his mouth. Histopathology of a biopsy specimen stained with methenamine silver is shown below. The most likely diagnosis is

A 12-year old girl presents to the general practitioner complaining of intense itching and blistering of the hands, arms, and legs. She states that she just returned from a school trip to a nature camp. Which of the following are the most likely medical condition and the correct hypersensitivity diagram from those presented ?
questions.correct_answer: C. Contact dermatitis and type IV

questions.text: A 38 -year-old patient during an elective surgery is transfused with two units of blood of which one unit is patients own preserved blood which was preserved a week back for use during the planned surgery, and one unit is his 30-year-old brother’s blood with the blood bank. This type of donation is most likely which of the following transplantation terminology (patient’s blood:brother’s blood)?

During evaluation for an insurance policy a 25 year old patient is found to have C5 through C9 complement deficiency, this patient is most likely to be susceptible to which of the following infections?

A 30 year old mother and her newborn are exposed to a pathogen while at the hospital for a routine checkup with pediatrician. This same pathogen had infected the mother about a year ago, and she had successfully recovered from the subsequent illness. Immunity may be innate or acquired. Which of the following best describes acquired immunity with respect to the newborn?
Which of the following statement best describes complement?

options.label: B
options.text: Complement is activated by IgE antibody classes

options.label: C
options.text: Complement plays a minor role in the inflammatory response

options.label: D
options.text: Complement protects the host from pneumococcal infection through C1, C2, and C4

questions.correct_answer: D. Complement protects the host from pneumococcal infection through C1, C2, and C4

questions.text: A 45 year old patient form tribal area presents with generalized myalgia and a low-grade fever, the patient has a long history of consuming poorly cooked pork meat. The physician orders a striated muscle biopsy which reveals multiple cysts. Eosinophilia is also present with elevated levels of which of the following immunoglobulins most likely involved in parasitic infections?

A 9 year old child presents with a low-grade fever, coryza, sore throat, a bright red rash on his cheeks, and a less intense erythematous rash on his body. Elevated IgG and IgM antibody titers are likely to be found to which of the following diseases ?

A 43-year-old man working in a slaughter house presents to the PHC medical officer with sudden, influenza-like symptoms. The patient adds that several of his coworkers have similar symptoms. Early stages of pneumonia are detected. Which of the following is the most likely etiologic organism?

A 34 year-old truck driver presents to the STD clinic with symptoms of a suspected sexually transmitted disease (STD). Neisseria and chlamydia agents are ruled out. Which of the following organisms is the most likely cause of his nongonococcal urethritis (NGU)?

A 28-year-old college student presents to the in campus clinic with a 2-week history of a penile ulcer. On asking he adds that this ulcer did not hurt. Among the following options which is most valid one ?

options.label: A
options.text: Draw blood for a herpes antibody test

options.label: B
options.text: Even if treated, the lesion will remain for months

options.label: C
options.text: Failure to treat the patient will have no untoward effect, as this is a self-limiting infection

options.label: D
options.text: Perform a dark-field examination of the lesion

questions.correct_answer: D. Perform a dark-field examination of the lesion

questions.text: A 51 year old patient is hospitalized with complaint of sepsis developed in a surgical wound. The patient is treated with tobramycin, carbenicillin, and clindamycin. Five days after antibiotic therapy was initiated, the patient develops severe diarrhea and pseudomembranous enterocolitis. Pseudomembranous enterocolitis can be caused by which of the following organisms?

A 13-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician with complaints of fever, malaise, and anorexia followed by tender swelling of his parotid glands. Which of the following is the most likely complication to occur in this patient?

A 3-month-old infant is brought to the casualty with complaints of fever, severe cough, wheezing and rapid breathing. Patient is admitted and an immunofluorescent assay is ordered which comes positive for a respiratory virus. As the infant was struggling to breathe, ribavirin treatment was started immediately. With which virus was this infant infected?
